Title: The structural organization of cingulate cortex: Areas, neurons and somatodendritic receptors.

@InterMapRelations.Comments: Fig. 1 of VPR87 is almost entirely identical to Fig. 1.11 of V93, the only difference being that areas 24a, 24b, 24c have been subdivided in V93 into  24a, 24b, 24c proper and 24a´, 24b´, 24c´.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Matelli et al. (1991) referred to this as area 24d. Here this area is termed 24c´..." (p. 34)

"Area 29 has two divisions. The lateral division is the least differentiated and has been variously referred to as area RSg1 (Vogt, 1976), area 29a-c (Vogt, 1985) or area 29l (Insausti et al., 1987)." (p. 36)

"Area 29 has two divisions. The lateral division is the least differentiated and has been variously referred to as area RSg1 (Vogt, 1976), area 29a-c (Vogt, 1985) or area 29l (Insausti et al., 1987)." (p. 36)

"Area 29 has two divisions. The lateral division is the least differentiated and has been variously referred to as area RSg1 (Vogt, 1976), area 29a-c (Vogt, 1985) or area 29l (Insausti et al., 1987)." (p. 36)

"Area 29 has two divisions. The lateral division is the least differentiated and has been variously referred to as area RSg1 (Vogt, 1976), area 29a-c (Vogt, 1985) or area 29l (Insausti et al., 1987)." (p. 36)

"Area 29 has two divisions. The lateral division is the least differentiated and has been variously referred to as area RSg1 (Vogt, 1976), area 29a-c (Vogt, 1985) or area 29l (Insausti et al., 1987)." (p. 36)
"Area 29 has two divisions. The lateral division is the least differentiated...Area 29m is medial to area 29l..." (p. 36)
"Area 29 has two divisions. The lateral division is the least differentiated...Area 29m is medial to area 29l..." (p. 36)

"In addition to architectural differences, there is connectional evidence that anterior and posterior parts of area 24 differ. As discussed in Chapter 8 of this volumen, the dense projections of the amygdala to layers Ic and II are to the anterior but not posterior part of area 24. Also, area 24´ appears to have more restricted intracingulate connections than does rostral areas 24." (p. 35)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: It appears, but is not entirely clear that area 24´is completely contained in VPR87-24. In his later work Vogt expresses the idea that 24´ contains also a rostral part of Brodmann's area 23

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "In addition [to area 24c], areas 24a and 24b also have caudal extensions that are indicated with a prime." (p. 34) "Fig. 1.11 is a reconstruction of the distribution of areas in the rhesus monkey's cingulate gyrus. This reconstruction includes areas 24 and 24´. In addition to architectural differences, there is connectional evidence that anterior and posterior parts of area 24 differ." (pp. 34-35)
